content: University will most likely be different to anything you have experienced before. You will be living with people from all over the world, taking responsibility for your own education, and looking after yourself. Before you arrive, take a look around and ensure that you are aware of what's expected of you, and what you can do to make the most of your time here.

metadata.title: Getting started
key_points: University life is different from previous experiences
You'll live with people from around the world
Take responsibility for your education and self-care
Be aware of expectations and opportunities

content: Your department may send you a reading list in advance and you will be able to explore the resources before you even arrive at Imperial on the Library website. Think about what equipment will work best for you. A laptop isn't essential but can be very useful, or you might prefer to stock up on notepads, pens, highlighters and post-it notes and make use of the College computers.

metadata.title: What to do before you arrive
key_points: Check for reading lists from your department
Explore library resources in advance
Consider what equipment you'll need (laptop, stationery, etc.)
Familiarize yourself with College computer resources

content: For each course, module, lecture or tutorial, the tutor will often refer you to certain text books, articles, videos or resources to prepare. For some courses, a reading list will be provided at the start of the year. This will often be supplemented by recommended reading via a Virtual Learning Environment such as Blackboard.

metadata.title: Reading lists
key_points: Tutors provide resources for preparation
Reading lists may be provided at start of year
Additional reading recommendations via Virtual Learning Environment
Library resources available for textbooks and articles

content: It is not essential to have your own computer, but most students choose to as it is beneficial to be able to study and write assignments at home rather than just in the library or department. Online learning plays a large part during your time at university so you should expect that there will be lots of online resources and activities for you to complete.

metadata.title: Study equipment and technology
key_points: Personal computer not essential but beneficial
Online learning is a significant part of university studies
Expect online resources and activities
Consider mobility needs when choosing equipment

content: There's a lot to do when you arrive at Imperial. Follow our quick checklist to ensure you don't miss anything important, and that you make the best start you can to your time here. The transition from school to university can be a challenge. Use the resources on this page to find out more about support available to you as you start your degree and for advice on how to manage the transition.

metadata.title: What to do when you get here
key_points: Follow the checklist to ensure you don't miss anything
Transition from school to university can be challenging
Resources available to support your transition
Advice provided on managing the transition

content: The transition from school to university is an exciting experience, but it can be challenging at times too. You may feel some uncertainty as you find your place in a new academic community and encounter different forms of learning and teaching than what you may have experienced at school. All of these feelings are very normal.

metadata.title: Adjusting to university study
key_points: Transition to university is exciting but can be challenging
Uncertainty is normal when entering new academic community
Learning and teaching methods may differ from school
These feelings are common among new students

content: Imperial has a number of campuses in London and the South East and it will take you a little while to find your way around. Don't worry - in your first few weeks and months everyone else will be finding their way around too. You can find out more about each campus below, or take a look at our campus maps.

metadata.title: Finding your way around Imperial College London
key_points: Imperial has multiple campuses in London and South East
It takes time to familiarize with all locations
Everyone is in the same situation in the first few weeks
Campus maps are available for reference

content: By studying at Imperial, you automatically become part of our Imperial community â€“ a network of students, staff, alumni and supporters who can support you and help you make the most of your time here. There are countless opportunities to get involved in many different ways, all of which will allow you to enjoy your time at Imperial, make friends and quite often, build your knowledge and skills to help you in whatever you choose to do in the future.

metadata.title: Getting Involved with the Imperial Community
key_points: Become part of the Imperial community as a student
Network includes students, staff, alumni, and supporters
Many opportunities to get involved and make friends
Build knowledge and skills for future endeavors

content: During your time at university, it is important to maintain a healthy work-life balance, specifically knowing when to work and when to rest. Clubs, Societies & Projects (CSPs) can be an important part of this balance. Imperial offers over 340 CSPs in the following categories: academic, arts & entertainment, charitable, cultural, departmental, faith, indoor, outdoor, martial arts, media, social and sports.

metadata.title: Student Clubs and Societies
key_points: Maintain a healthy work-life balance
Clubs, Societies & Projects (CSPs) contribute to balance
Over 340 CSPs available in various categories
Opportunities for academic, social, and personal growth

content: Throughout the year, we host a diverse and broad range of workshops and events to enhance your academic skills. Attending these workshops can help you learn new skills, build your confidence in these skills and get feedback from peers and tutors.

metadata.title: Academic Skills Workshops
key_points: Diverse range of workshops and events offered
Helps enhance academic skills
Provides opportunity for skill-building and feedback

content: The Library Services pages will help you progress through four stages of your assignment: Prepare it, Find it, Use it, and Write it. These pages are designed to allow you to work through them from start to finish, or you can dip in and out of the information depending on which stage you are at in your assignments.

metadata.title: Assignment strategies
key_points: Library Services provides guidance on assignment stages
Covers Prepare it, Find it, Use it, and Write it
Flexible resource for different stages of assignment

content: The Careers Service offers a range of workshops to help explore, plan and get the job or postgraduate study option that is right for you. These run throughout the year at a variety of times to help fit around all timetables. Careers Essentials are 1 hour sessions to help you get started on a range of topics including LinkedIn, application tools, interviews, and assessment centers.

metadata.title: Careers Workshops
key_points: Careers Service offers various workshops
Helps with job search and postgraduate study planning
Includes topics like LinkedIn, applications, and interviews

content: Imposter syndrome can often result in anxiety and self-doubt. To combat this, be open about your feelings, document your achievements, reframe defeats as learning opportunities, and remember that you've been accepted into one of the top universities in the world. Don't forget that there is always support available to help you manage these feelings.

metadata.title: Imposter Syndrome
key_points: Imposter syndrome can cause anxiety and self-doubt
Strategies include openness, documenting achievements, and reframing defeats
Remember your accomplishments and available support

content: Each department has a different system for assigning tutors to students. You may have a personal tutor who can advise you about academic progress and offer guidance on welfare issues. You may have a separate academic tutor for subject-specific information. Make sure you know who your contact is â€“ they will then be able to let you know where to go or who to talk to when you need help.

metadata.title: In your department
key_points: Tutor assignment systems vary by department
May have personal tutor for academic and welfare guidance
Separate academic tutor may be available for subject-specific help

content: There are many sources of support at Imperial College. These include your academic department, Student Services (which includes Careers, Chaplaincy, Counselling, and Disability Advisory Service), the ICU Advice Centre, health services, and various support services like the Library, Careers Service, and Centre for Academic English. Don't hesitate to reach out when you need help.

metadata.title: Who to ask for help
key_points: Multiple support sources available at Imperial
Includes academic department, Student Services, and ICU Advice Centre
Specialized services like Library and Careers Service also offer support

content: Take responsibility for your learning and shape your experience. Make it what you want it to be.

metadata.title: 1. University study is about independence
key_points: Take responsibility for your own learning
Shape your university experience
Be proactive in your education

content: The more you ask, the more you will learn. No one knows everything.

metadata.title: 2. Participate and ask questions
key_points: Asking questions leads to more learning
Don't be afraid to seek clarification
Everyone is still learning, even experts

content: Results show that those who attend classes get better marks than those who do not. This goes for remote classes too!

metadata.title: 3. Don't skip your classes
key_points: Attendance correlates with better marks
Applies to both in-person and remote classes
Regular attendance is crucial for success

content: They can help with any problems. You might not need them right away, but you might need them later.

metadata.title: 4. Keep in touch with your personal tutor
key_points: Personal tutors can help with various problems
Maintain contact even if immediate help isn't needed
They're a valuable resource for future challenges

content: Organise your time around lectures, reading, tutorials, the library and Clubs & Societies. Make time for you to dance, swim, walk, sing and relax.

metadata.title: 5. Learn to manage your time
key_points: Organize time for academic and extracurricular activities
Include time for relaxation and hobbies
Balance study with personal interests

content: Everyone is new. Speak to classmates, form study groups and try a new sport. Step outside your comfort zone.

metadata.title: 6. Make friends
key_points: Everyone is new and in the same situation
Engage with classmates and form study groups
Try new activities to meet people

content: It's given to help you improve your work and your grades. Give feedback, we like to improve too.

metadata.title: 7. Use feedback
key_points: Feedback helps improve work and grades
Actively use the feedback you receive
Provide feedback to help improve the university

content: Don't just stick to the lecture notes. Expand your knowledge.

metadata.title: 8. Read around your subject
key_points: Go beyond lecture notes
Expand your knowledge of the subject
Explore additional resources and materials

content: Feed your brain with thinking fuel. Can't cook? Learn. Whether you're a night owl, or an early bird, make sure you sleep. While you sleep, your body is working to maintain your health.

metadata.title: 9. Eat, sleep and look after yourself
key_points: Maintain a healthy diet
Ensure adequate sleep
Prioritize self-care and health

content: You are living in one of the greatest, most diverse, cities in the world. Explore, discover, and experience the city, it's all part of being an Imperial student.

metadata.title: 10. Enjoy London
key_points: London is a diverse and exciting city
Take time to explore and discover
Experiencing the city is part of being an Imperial student

content: An Imperial education is not just about the cutting-edge knowledge you'll gain while studying for your degree. You will experience all kinds of different learning activities in your programme of study, providing you with skills to develop your academic and professional career. You will be required to plan and manage your own workload, organise group work and projects with new people and deliver presentations and projects as a team.

metadata.title: Effective study
key_points: Imperial education goes beyond subject knowledge
Diverse learning activities develop academic and professional skills
Self-management of workload and group projects is required
Presentation and teamwork skills are emphasized

content: Thinking critically is one of the most important skills you will develop whilst at university, and at the heart of critical thinking, is questioning. Questioning lecturers, questioning research and information, and questioning ourselves. By asking the right questions, you will find you are closer to the right answers.

metadata.title: Asking questions
key_points: Critical thinking is a crucial skill developed at university
Questioning is at the heart of critical thinking
Ask questions of lecturers, research, and yourself
Asking the right questions leads to better answers

content: The GROW model offers a learner-centred approach to structuring a conversation or thinking independently about an issue, to help a person move from setting a goal to identifying next steps include a time frame.

metadata.title: Coaching
key_points: GROW model is a learner-centered approach
Helps structure conversations or independent thinking
Assists in moving from goal-setting to action planning
Includes timeframe considerations in planning

content: Learning as the process of receiving and storing information in memory. Learning as the process of working together with others to solve a problem or complete a task. Learning as the process of sharing, discussing and debating ideas and concepts with other students or teachers.

metadata.title: How will you learn at Imperial?
key_points: Learning involves receiving and storing information
Collaborative problem-solving and task completion
Sharing, discussing, and debating ideas with peers and teachers
Multiple approaches to learning are employed

content: Lectures will form a considerable portion of your learning at university. Find out what to expect from lectures and how to make the most of them. Have you ever thought about why or how you take notes? There are lots of different reasons for note-taking and different techniques depending on the purpose.

metadata.title: In class and in lectures
key_points: Lectures are a major part of university learning
Understanding lecture expectations is important
Various reasons and techniques for note-taking exist
Effective note-taking enhances learning

content: Whilst most of your teaching at Imperial College will be in-person, there may be times when teaching or personal & professional development workshops are delivered online. There are a number of different ways in which your teachers might choose to deliver teaching online, so you should expect that there will be variety in how remote classes will be taught.

metadata.title: Learning Online
key_points: Most teaching is in-person, but some may be online
Various methods for online teaching delivery
Expect variety in remote class formats
Be prepared for both in-person and online learning

content: Reflect regularly on whether your study techniques are effective and be aware of the best times in the day for your study. It may be the case that you work better in the mornings but have planned lots of evening work therefore you will have to adjust your schedule.

metadata.title: Time management
key_points: Regularly reflect on study technique effectiveness
Identify your most productive times of day
Adjust your schedule to match your productivity patterns
Be flexible in your time management approach

content: As well as Blackboard, our Virtual Learning Environment, you will find that a lot of resources and information that you need is online. Online tools can be a huge advantage, but they can also be a distraction or a hindrance. Follow our advice for working online.

metadata.title: Working by yourself
key_points: Blackboard is the primary Virtual Learning Environment
Many resources and information are available online
Online tools can be both advantageous and distracting
Follow advice for effective online work

content: Need some help co-ordinating your group activities? We have some useful tools and techniques for you to try. Team work is important in the workplace as well as at university and employers are very keen to see this skill in graduates. Use this time to perfect your skills.

metadata.title: Working with others
key_points: Tools and techniques available for group activities
Teamwork is important in university and workplace
Employers value teamwork skills in graduates
University is a time to develop teamwork skills

content: When you're working from your desk on a regular basis, it's important that you find a good place to work. Find a quiet place with a good internet connection, access to power sources, and free from any unnecessary distractions.

metadata.title: Workspace
key_points: Finding a good workspace is crucial for regular study
Seek a quiet place with good internet and power access
Minimize unnecessary distractions in your workspace
A proper workspace enhances productivity

content: You will be assessed in a number of different ways during your degree, often depending on your subject choice. Find out about the different forms of assessment you'll come across in your time at Imperial. Throughout your course you'll be expected to produce reports, essays and other written assignments. We're here to help you understand what's required and produce clear, original writing.

metadata.title: Assessments & feedback
key_points: Various forms of assessment used during your degree
Assessments include reports, essays, and written assignments
Support available to understand requirements
Emphasis on clear and original writing

content: Learning how to express your own ideas and discuss those of others in writing is an important academic skill. By planning your writing properly before you start, your writing will be clearer and more effective. 'Academic writing' does not just mean 'formal writing'. Check out these useful writing tips to help write clearly and for the right audience.

metadata.title: Academic writing
key_points: Expressing ideas in writing is a crucial academic skill
Proper planning leads to clearer, more effective writing
Academic writing is not just formal writing
Tips available for clear writing and audience consideration

content: Presentations are a useful way to test your oral communication skills and your ability to prepare information for different audiences. After every assessment, you will get useful feedback. Be reassured by what you've done well, and use the feedback to focus your efforts for your next assignment.

metadata.title: Delivering presentations
key_points: Presentations test oral communication skills
Ability to prepare information for different audiences is assessed
Feedback provided after every assessment
Use feedback to improve future assignments

content: Preparing for exams starts much earlier than the night before; we'll help you avoid the last-minute panic. You'll need to make sure you take good and useful notes throughout your course in order to be fully prepared for your exams.

metadata.title: Examinations
key_points: Exam preparation should start well before the exam date
Good note-taking throughout the course is essential
Guidance available to avoid last-minute panic
Effective preparation leads to better exam performance

content: Your feedback about your experience at Imperial is really important to the institution. Feedback helps us to improve and enhance the experience students have here. There are plenty of ways to give feedback about your experience here. For example, you could: Complete surveys, such as the Student Online Evaluation (SOLE), the Student Experience Survey (SES), or the National Student Survey (NSS).

metadata.title: Giving feedback to staff
key_points: Student feedback is crucial for improving Imperial
Multiple ways to provide feedback are available
Surveys like SOLE, SES, and NSS are used to gather feedback
Feedback helps enhance student experience

content: You will receive feedback in several ways while at university. Feedback may not just come from your tutor â€“ it could come from unexpected sources. Applying feedback is essential to academic development. One of the keys to success at university is making full use of any feedback you receive.

metadata.title: Improving through feedback
key_points: Feedback comes in various forms and from different sources
Applying feedback is crucial for academic development
Making full use of feedback is key to university success
Be open to feedback from unexpected sources

content: If you find yourself rushing through the questions, purposefully slow down. Try and avoid skim-reading or scrolling too quickly. It's common to hold your breath or breathe shallowly when nervous. Purposefully pause regularly to inhale for at least 3 seconds and exhale for longer.

metadata.title: Keeping calm in exams
key_points: Slow down if rushing through questions
Avoid skim-reading or quick scrolling
Practice deep breathing to manage nervousness
Regular pauses can help maintain calm

content: This method of assessment is similar to a traditional "test" that you might have taken at school. They are a highly efficient and targeted way of testing a specific area of knowledge, and they'll let your tutor build up a good picture of how comprehensive your knowledge is.

metadata.title: Problem Sheets
key_points: Similar to traditional school tests
Efficient for testing specific knowledge areas
Helps tutors gauge comprehensiveness of knowledge

content: Working in a laboratory environment requires a special set of skills, and these assessments will examine your ability to handle equipment confidently, competently and safely. Follow-up reports will show how well you have understood the underlying scientific principles behind the work.

metadata.title: Laboratory work and lab reports
key_points: Tests special skills required for lab work
Assesses ability to handle equipment safely and competently
Follow-up reports evaluate understanding of scientific principles

content: Oral presentations test your ability to communicate effectively with others in a clear, concise and interesting way. You may also be asked questions after a presentation, which will assess the depth of your knowledge and your ability to deal with unexpected situations.

metadata.title: Presentations
key_points: Tests effective communication skills
Assesses ability to present clearly and interestingly
Questions after presentation test depth of knowledge and adaptability

content: These test your ability to work with others. Different people bring different strengths to a project, and you will need to develop an understanding of the roles individuals play â€“ as well as your own contribution to the team.

metadata.title: Group projects
key_points: Tests ability to work collaboratively
Requires understanding of different roles in a team
Assesses individual contribution within a group context

content: Essays and reports are an effective way for you to demonstrate many of the desired skills you should be learning on your course - critical analysis, qualitative knowledge, mathematical and logical skills, and written communication capability.

metadata.title: Essays and reports
key_points: Demonstrates critical analysis skills
Shows qualitative knowledge and logical thinking
Tests mathematical skills and written communication

content: Written exams can be used to demonstrate all the skills you use in writing essays and reports, but under a different set of conditions. They also test your ability to use these skills under pressure and without help from anyone else.

metadata.title: Written exams
key_points: Tests skills similar to essays and reports
Assesses ability to work under pressure
Evaluates independent work without external help

content: Formative assessment helps you to improve. It doesn't count towards your final degree, but the lessons you learn through doing this type of assessment will help you to achieve a better final grade. For this reason the feedback you get on formative assessments is very important â€“ this will tell you where your weak points are, and what you need to do to improve.

metadata.title: Formative Assessments
key_points: Helps improve skills but doesn't count towards final grade
Provides important feedback for improvement
Identifies weak points and areas for development

content: Summative assessment measures how well you've done. All summative assessment counts towards your final degree, and is likely to happen at the end of a set period (term, semester, academic year, etc.). The feedback from this work will show you how well you have performed - and what your next steps should be.

metadata.title: Summative Assessments
key_points: Measures overall performance
Counts towards final degree
Typically occurs at the end of academic periods
Provides feedback on performance and future steps

content: To continue to develop your communication skills during your doctorate, you have access to a range of College expertise: Your Supervisor will provide feedback on your work, particularly on the scientific aspect of your writing. The Centre for Academic English provides extensive support to develop academic STEMM communication competence. The Library offers support on information management, optimising search criteria, managing references, preparing thesis for open access, and selecting copyright licence for your work. The Graduate School will support you through the process of producing a thesis, grant application, or publication, focusing on their structure and audience.

metadata.title: Communicating your research
key_points: Various College resources for developing communication skills
Support available for scientific writing and STEMM communication
Assistance with information management and thesis preparation

content: The primary responsibility for supervision of your postgraduate studies lies with your supervisor. They are responsible for overseeing your progress, ensuring you undertake appropriate training courses, follow safety guidelines, and making funds available for your studies. Postdocs play an important role in helping to supervise many postgraduate students on a day-to-day basis. The Director of Postgraduate Studies (DPS) is responsible for implementing postgraduate education policy. Your department will have at least one Senior Tutor (PGR) who has overall responsibility for the academic and pastoral care of postgraduate students.

metadata.title: Key People
key_points: Supervisor is primary responsible for overseeing your studies
Postdocs provide day-to-day supervision support
Various roles exist to support postgraduate students

content: A research degree is a very individual experience, more so than an undergraduate degree. While the overarching structure will be identical or similar across the university, individual research projects, research interactions and assessment interactions will differ. This environment can provide a rich learning experience for student cohorts discussing their experiences. Perhaps for the first time, you will be given the opportunity to explore a subject or problem that has not been explored before. This does not mean that you are on your own, but that you are embedded into a local and even global community of like-minded people, who work in a similar area or have a common interest.

metadata.title: How is a research degree different?
key_points: Research degree is a highly individual experience
Opportunity to explore novel subjects or problems
Part of a community of like-minded researchers

content: Be open about your feelings and recognise when they emerge. It's important to talk to those close to you about your concerns to help you get a sense of perspective. You are likely to discover that you are not alone. Document your achievements as you go along to challenge any feelings of inadequacy. Be proud of your accomplishments and learn to accept compliments from others. Don't forget that you have been accepted onto a research degree at one of the top universities in the world. There may be times when working in a pressurised environment may seem overwhelming, however it's important to remember that you are not alone and there is always support available to help you to manage these feelings.

metadata.title: You Belong Here
key_points: Be open about feelings and talk to others
Document achievements to combat impostor syndrome
Remember your accomplishments and available support

content: The Student Counselling Service provides individual counselling for registered students at the College for any personal issues that may be affecting your wellbeing. We also offer some Life Skills workshops and online support groups. The Disability Advisory Service is committed to providing the best possible support for all students at Imperial. We understand that each person's disability or impairment can affect them in different ways and therefore the support offered is flexible and tailored.

metadata.title: Health and Wellbeing
key_points: Student Counselling Service available for personal issues
Life Skills workshops and online support groups offered
Disability Advisory Service provides tailored support

content: The Imperial College Union supports a variety of student-led activities that you can get involved in. Be a volunteer at different Imperial events such as Graduation or Welcome Week. Join to start exercising, take part in classes or become an Imperial athlete. One common challenge for PhD students is to maintain a work-life balance. Check what you can do to keep this balance.

metadata.title: Life outside of your PhD
key_points: Various student-led activities available
Opportunities for volunteering and sports
Importance of maintaining work-life balance

content: For some students, different stages of their research can be more challenging and daunting than others. Your supervisor and Senior Tutor as well as other members of your department/group will be there to support you at all times. If you need advice on dealing with stress or pressure during your research degree, visit the Student Support Zone.

metadata.title: Main stages of the PhD
key_points: Different stages can be challenging for some students
Support available from supervisor and department
Student Support Zone for stress and pressure advice

content: Test yourself by doing some practice questions. Ask your supervisor to provide you with a list of questions that they would anticipate may be asked. Identify areas that you are uncertain about and discuss further with your supervisor if you have concerns about what you could be questioned on. You may find your supervisor or department will automatically organise a mock viva. If not, ask your supervisor if they will conduct a mock viva with you, perhaps including another member of the research team who is familiar with your research work and could ask you relevant questions.

metadata.title: The Viva
key_points: Practice with anticipated questions
Identify and discuss uncertain areas with supervisor
Participate in mock viva for preparation

content: You can access support in your academic department from a number of different sources and you can choose the one that is right for you. Student Services is made up of a range of specialist student facing support services, including Careers, the Chaplaincy, the Counselling and Mental Health Advice Service, the Disability Advisory Service and the Sexual Violence Liaison Team. The ICU Advice Centre is a free, confidential, non-judgemental and independent service for all students studying at Imperial College.

metadata.title: Support
key_points: Multiple sources of support available in academic department
Student Services offers specialist support services
ICU Advice Centre provides independent support

content: Developing a research identity will be personal to you, involve self-reflection and happen through a variety of ways. Impostor syndrome feelings are common among doctoral students, but it can be addressed in different ways and support is available.

metadata.title: Transitioning to a research degree
key_points: Research identity development is personal and reflective
Impostor syndrome is common among doctoral students
Support available for addressing impostor syndrome

content: Your supervisor should be supportive of you both intellectually and personally, set up a viable project, provide an adequate work space, be available to talk about research problems, help and guide you throughout your PhD journey, help develop your skills, enable you to attend conferences, provide resources, and read your thesis thoroughly. As a student, you are expected to display initiative, develop your skills, keep up with your field, provide regular reports, be aware of safety, understand your funding, process expenses claims, be self-critical, collaborate with others, and share your findings.

metadata.title: Working with your supervisor
key_points: Supervisor provides intellectual and personal support
Students expected to show initiative and develop skills
Mutual expectations for successful PhD journey

content: A research degree is likely to be very different to any other training or degree you may have undertaken previously. There is key information that you need to know before starting doctoral study at Imperial. There is guidance to support you.

metadata.title: Preparing for your PhD
key_points: Research degree differs from previous academic experiences
Important information needed before starting doctoral study
Guidance available to support new PhD students

content: The primary responsibility for supervision of your postgraduate studies lies with your supervisor. Your supervisor is responsible for overseeing your progress during your studies, ensuring that you undertake appropriate training courses, follow safety guidelines and making funds available for you to successfully undertake your studies. Further supervision may also be provided by one or more co-supervisors - typically where your research involves collaboration with another research group, or where your primary supervisor is a new member of academic staff.

metadata.title: Key People
key_points: Supervisor is primary responsibility for postgraduate studies
Supervisor oversees progress, training, and funding
Co-supervisors may be involved in collaborative research

content: Find out more information about types of funding for doctoral studies. Find out more about the College expectations with respect to paid work during your studies and what to do if you have financial concerns. You can also access Blackbullion, which is free to all Imperial students and gives access to a full range of online learning pathways and tools to help you manage your finances and build yourself a better financial future.

metadata.title: Know your finances
key_points: Information available on doctoral funding types
College expectations on paid work during studies
Access to Blackbullion for financial management tools

content: The MRes is a postgraduate qualification, awarded on the results of examinations following a course of advanced study, normally taking one year full-time to complete. The PhD is the most common kind of doctoral programme. Normally it takes at least three years full time to complete, the majority of which is spent carrying out original research. To complete the PhD you will need to submit a thesis of up to 100,000 words. You will also be examined orally (known as a viva voce examination) by two or more examiners, both internal and external to the College.

metadata.title: What is a research degree?
key_points: MRes is a one-year postgraduate qualification
PhD typically takes at least three years full-time
PhD requires thesis submission and oral examination

content: Undertaking a research degree is part of a training, professional and personal development process, which will be life-long. There will be little or no set timetable of lectures and there are no formal term dates. Research degrees can start at any time of the academic year, although the majority of Imperial students tend to commence their studies in October. You will acquire a high degree of self-management, which will be required for you to succeed in managing your day, your research, your degree and its requirements.

metadata.title: How is a research degree different?
key_points: Research degree is a lifelong development process
No set timetable or formal term dates
High degree of self-management required

content: The Imperial College Union supports a variety of student-led activities that you can get involved in. Be a volunteer at different Imperial events such as Graduation or Welcome Week. Join to start exercising, take part in classes or become an Imperial athlete. One common challenge for PhD students is to maintain a work-life balance. Check what you can do to keep this balance.

metadata.title: Life outside of your PhD
key_points: Various student-led activities available
Opportunities for volunteering and sports
Importance of maintaining work-life balance

content: For some students, different stages of their research can be more challenging and daunting than others. Your supervisor and Senior Tutor as well as other members of your department/group will be there to support you at all times. If you need advice on dealing with stress or pressure during your research degree, visit the Student Support Zone.

metadata.title: Main stages of the PhD
key_points: Different stages can be challenging for some students
Support available from supervisor and department
Student Support Zone for stress and pressure advice

content: Test yourself by doing some practice questions. Ask your supervisor to provide you with a list of questions that they would anticipate may be asked. Identify areas that you are uncertain about and discuss further with your supervisor if you have concerns about what you could be questioned on. You may find your supervisor or department will automatically organise a mock viva. If not, ask your supervisor if they will conduct a mock viva with you, perhaps including another member of the research team who is familiar with your research work and could ask you relevant questions.

metadata.title: The Viva
key_points: Practice with anticipated questions
Identify and discuss uncertain areas with supervisor
Participate in mock viva for preparation

content: You can access support in your academic department from a number of different sources and you can choose the one that is right for you. Student Services is made up of a range of specialist student facing support services, including Careers, the Chaplaincy, the Counselling and Mental Health Advice Service, the Disability Advisory Service and the Sexual Violence Liaison Team. The ICU Advice Centre is a free, confidential, non-judgemental and independent service for all students studying at Imperial College.

metadata.title: Support
key_points: Multiple sources of support available in academic department
Student Services offers specialist support services
ICU Advice Centre provides independent support

content: Developing a research identity will be personal to you, involve self-reflection and happen through a variety of ways. Impostor syndrome feelings are common among doctoral students, but it can be addressed in different ways and support is available.

metadata.title: Transitioning to a research degree
key_points: Research identity development is personal and reflective
Impostor syndrome is common among doctoral students
Support available for addressing impostor syndrome

content: Your supervisor should be supportive of you both intellectually and personally, set up a viable project, provide an adequate work space, be available to talk about research problems, help and guide you throughout your PhD journey, help develop your skills, enable you to attend conferences, provide resources, and read your thesis thoroughly. As a student, you are expected to display initiative, develop your skills, keep up with your field, provide regular reports, be aware of safety, understand your funding, process expenses claims, be self-critical, collaborate with others, and share your findings.

metadata.title: Working with your supervisor
key_points: Supervisor provides intellectual and personal support
Students expected to show initiative and develop skills
Mutual expectations for successful PhD journey

content: Throughout your doctoral journey you will develop your disciplinary knowledge and skills, and also many research and other professional, transferable skills. These skills will help you to navigate successfully through your PhD research challenges, and contribute towards building a strong professional and academic profile for your future career. Imperial College offers you many options and opportunities to develop your skills and broaden your outlook.

metadata.title: Developing your Research and Professional Skills
key_points: Develop disciplinary knowledge and transferable skills
Skills help navigate PhD challenges and build professional profile
Imperial offers various opportunities for skill development

content: During your PhD you will be expected to produce many written documents, such as your initial research plan, ESA report, LSR report, funding applications, conference papers, journal articles and abstracts, posters, and your Thesis. You will have many opportunities to communicate and discuss your research verbally with your peers, the public, and other academics and experts, when presenting in conferences, building networks, running public engagement activities, explaining your research decisions, and at the Viva.

metadata.title: Communicating your research
key_points: Produce various written documents throughout PhD
Verbal communication opportunities in conferences and networking
Develop skills for public engagement and research explanation

content: Be aware that disabilities, health conditions, mental health difficulties and specific learning difficulties can have an impact on the thinking skills associated with organisation and time management. If you would like to discuss issues around these matters, please book an appointment with the disability advisory service where you can get support for an existing condition or help in securing a possible diagnostic assessment. The Graduate School offers courses to develop your skills to better manage your time and your research project.

metadata.title: Managing time
key_points: Health conditions can impact organization and time management skills
Disability advisory service available for support
Graduate School offers courses on time management

content: The Library offers you more information and links to courses available across Imperial in the Open research education to doctoral students page, as well as ways to connect with the Imperial open research community.

metadata.title: Practicing open research
key_points: Library provides information on open research education
Courses available across Imperial for open research
Connect with Imperial open research community

content: The Graduate School's Research Computing and Data Science Programme (RCDS) teaches short, hands-on courses ranging from introductory to advanced topics. All Graduate School tutors have research backgrounds and will help you to develop new skills to underpin your research project. There is also a Useful Resources section to further support you. This group manages and supports the high performance computing (HPC) cluster. Specialised training, user support via ASK Imperial and weekly Teams clinics are available.

metadata.title: Research Computing and Data Skills
key_points: Graduate School offers hands-on courses in research computing
High performance computing (HPC) cluster available
Specialized training and support provided

content: During your Master's degree, you will be expected to explore new perspectives, pursue your own research and add your own voice to the community in your field. Master a new skill, take up a new sport or embrace a new challenge â€“ never again are you likely to have such freedom to learn about yourself and what you enjoy. The benefits of studying and researching at Imperial go beyond the lecture theatre. When you are planning how to make the most of your Imperial experience, consider how to use the resources at the College to your advantage.

metadata.title: Beyond academic life
key_points: Explore new perspectives and pursue own research
Opportunity to learn new skills and embrace challenges
Utilize College resources beyond academics

content: During your time at university, it is important to maintain a healthy work-life balance, specifically knowing when to work and when to rest. Clubs, Societies & Projects (CSPs) can be an important part of this balance. Imperial offers over 340 CSPs in various categories. The list of CSPs is very diverse, allowing you to continue a long-loved hobby or try something new. You can meet new people outside your course and from all around the world. You can also join a committee by running for a leadership position in October elections.

metadata.title: Your Social Life
key_points: Maintain a healthy work-life balance
Over 340 Clubs, Societies & Projects available
Opportunity to meet new people and develop leadership skills

content: Imperial works in partnership with institutions all over the world. This gives students the opportunity to get involved in high-profile international research projects, or experience university life in a completely different country. Make yourself aware of the notable projects in your field, and the overseas partners that you may be able to work with. By building up your personal networks, you will be able to discover and secure job opportunities that are not advertised elsewhere. Many Imperial researchers and staff in your field will have attractive contacts at high-profile universities and companies.

metadata.title: Using the Imperial community as a resource
key_points: Opportunities for international research projects
Build personal networks for job opportunities
Utilize Imperial's partnerships and staff connections

content: The College's Careers Service is a good port of call for support and guidance. You will be able to attend a variety of careers fairs and events throughout the year, where you will meet potential employers. Staff within your department will also be able to provide advice on careers, and you can book appointments with specialist consultants and placement advisors. The Careers Service also provides resources such as careers libraries, case studies, publications, guides to pursuing further study, and advice on CV writing, interviewing and networking.

metadata.title: Careers
key_points: Careers Service offers support and guidance
Attend careers fairs and events to meet potential employers
Resources available for CV writing, interviewing, and networking

content: During your Master's degree, you will be required to communicate in a variety of different ways. Strong communication and influencing skills are essential, not only as skills for education and studying, but also beyond into the workplace and the research environment. Learning how to communicate effectively with different audiences is hugely important in everything we do. This applies whether we are delivering a presentation, having a conversation, or writing something for a wider audience. In studying for a Master's degree, you will become something of an expert in your field. You will be expected to go beyond merely consuming knowledge and information, and start contributing to the understanding of the subject yourself.

metadata.title: Communicating and influencing
key_points: Develop strong communication skills for various contexts
Learn to communicate effectively with different audiences
Contribute to the understanding of your field

content: In writing tasks, you will usually need to demonstrate clear critical thinking skills to earn high marks. Weaker writing is more descriptive, and tends to describe a number of facts, figures and definitions without using this information to support a greater conclusion or hypothesis. While some description is beneficial, the reader will expect you to go somewhere with it. You will be expected to draw your own conclusions in your work, rather than simply parrot others. You will select the data and sources, and decide which evidence is stronger than others. As a result, you should not be afraid to make statements and judgements in your writing, regardless of whether you use the pronoun 'I' or not.

metadata.title: Academic writing
key_points: Demonstrate critical thinking skills in writing
Draw your own conclusions and make judgements
Use evidence to support your arguments

content: The key to giving a good presentation is preparation. Consider what you're trying to achieve, who your audience is, how you want to engage with them, and the venue where you'll be presenting. Structure your presentation clearly, including main points, supporting information, and linking sections. Practice your presentation with your supervisor, other research team members, or friends. To calm nerves, get a good night's sleep, take deep breaths, and remember that your audience wants to see you succeed. During the presentation, make eye contact, pace your delivery, vary your tone of voice, and use body language to emphasize points and appear confident.

metadata.title: Delivering presentations
key_points: Prepare thoroughly for presentations
Consider audience, venue, and engagement strategies
Practice delivery techniques and manage nerves

content: One of the most valuable skills you will learn as a postgraduate student will be to communicate and interact effectively with academics, staff and fellow students. You will have support from our staff, and will be expected to reach out to them if you experience any academic or personal issues. It is important to be aware that academics and researchers have busy schedules and have many competing demands on their time. To contact your lecturer, you could ask in person or send a brief, focused email. If you don't hear within a working day, don't be afraid to send a polite follow up. While you will be expected to demonstrate independence and initiative, postgraduate study is an excellent opportunity to connect with world-renowned experts and explore your professional development.

metadata.title: Interacting with academic staff
key_points: Learn to communicate effectively with academics and staff
Be aware of academics' busy schedules when contacting them
Balance independence with seeking support and connections

content: There are certain things you can do before you arrive to help support your studies. We have collected some information to help you plan effectively before you join your course. A Master's degree is undoubtedly a big commitment. It is inevitable that you're going to feel pushed for time sometimes. This is totally normal, but there are ways to make it easier on yourself. Most programmes are designed to be studied full-time, but some can be completed part-time. Both have expectations of attendance and independent study.

metadata.title: Getting started
key_points: Plan effectively before joining the course
Prepare for time management challenges
Understand expectations for full-time and part-time study

content: If coming to Imperial will be the first time you've studied at an English-medium academic institution, you might want to upgrade your academic communication skills before you begin. Imperial's Centre for Academic English runs a 3-week, full-time course in September to help you prepare for your first term. The intensive course gives you practice in, and feedback on, many aspects of academic communication, including report writing and giving presentations. Attributes and Aspirations (AA) is an online short course that supports you to adapt to masters study at Imperial and then decide on, and plan for whatever you want your professional future to be.

metadata.title: Before you arrive
key_points: Consider upgrading academic communication skills
Centre for Academic English offers preparatory courses
Attributes and Aspirations online course available for support

content: Some students may decide (for personal, medical or financial reasons) to take a temporary break in their studies. At Imperial, this is called an Interruption of Studies. To take a break in your studies, you need to get clearance from a personal tutor, course organiser or course director. Before you decide to take an interruption, it is vital that you discuss your circumstances with a member of your course team, so that they can provide you with the best possible guidance. If you are an international student and you are in the UK on a Student visa, you need to be aware that any change to your circumstances might impact on your visa and your ability to remain in the UK.

metadata.title: Breaks in study
key_points: Interruption of Studies available for temporary breaks
Discuss circumstances with course team before deciding
International students should be aware of visa implications

content: To complete your programme successfully, you will need to commit to studying fairly intensively over a certain period of time. As a result, it may not always be in your best interests to juggle employment with full-time study. The expectation is that no student's paid work should impact negatively on their studies, however, part-time programmes allow some flexibility for students who have other commitments. Before committing to a programme, it is vital that you understand what your fees are, and consider how you will support yourself while studying, including the cost of living in London, accommodation and fees.

metadata.title: Finances
key_points: Consider impact of employment on full-time study
Part-time programmes offer more flexibility
Understand fees and living costs before committing

content: You can access support in your academic department from a number of different sources and you can choose the one that is right for you. Student Services is made up of a range of specialist student facing support services, including Careers, the Chaplaincy, the Counselling and Mental Health Advice Service, the Disability Advisory Service and the Sexual Violence Liaison Team. The ICU Advice Centre is a free, confidential, non-judgemental and independent service for all students studying at Imperial College. The Student Counselling Service provides individual counselling for registered students at the College for any personal issues that may be affecting your wellbeing.

metadata.title: Support
key_points: Various support services available in academic departments
Student Services offers specialist support
ICU Advice Centre and Counselling Service available

content: Part-time courses involve committing yourself to study for a period of two to three years. Master's students are expected to take responsibility for their studies. However, we recognise that juggling a career and family with your academic life can be challenging. We have plenty of extra advice and support for part-time students, on issues such as working with others, making the most of the College community, and working remotely.

metadata.title: Part-time study
key_points: Part-time courses typically last 2-3 years
Students must balance career, family, and academic life
Support available for various aspects of part-time study

content: Part-time students with a group work project will need to master effective ways of working remotely as a team. You may be assigned to a group by your tutor, or be asked to form one yourselves based on your shared interests. You will need to assign roles and responsibilities when you convene the group, and agree how you will work together and communicate to achieve the task at hand. There are a variety of social activities, clubs, and open lectures at Imperial. Make sure you take the time to enjoy everything that the College has to offer.

metadata.title: Advice for part-time students
key_points: Develop effective remote teamwork skills
Assign roles and responsibilities in group projects
Engage in social activities and clubs at Imperial

content: Imperial's part-time programmes are designed to combine fixed teaching modules with online study that you can complete remotely in your own time. Some courses feature more extensive online learning than others. Your programme administrator will advise you of the dates of face-to-face teaching modules before the beginning of the academic year to enable study leave to be booked. A list of local hotels that offer Imperial students and visitors accommodation at reduced rates is available for when you need to attend on-campus modules.

metadata.title: Getting started for part-time students
key_points: Programs combine fixed modules with remote online study
Face-to-face teaching dates provided in advance
Accommodation options available for on-campus modules

content: You will be able to draw on plenty of support at Imperial as you complete your research project. Your department will ensure that you have an Imperial-based co-supervisor for your project, provide advice on identifying suitable projects, provide a monitoring framework to help you keep track of your progress, and produce regular reports. Some part-time students undertake their Master's research project at their workplace. In these cases, you will need to identify a suitable project that can comfortably be conducted in this setting, and find an appropriate local supervisor to support you.

metadata.title: Support for part-time students
key_points: Extensive support available for research projects
Imperial-based co-supervisor provided
Option to conduct research project at workplace

content: Part-time Master's students at Imperial usually enrol for either a two or three year period. If you enrol for a two-year Master's programme but discover that you will be unable to complete within two years, you may request to be moved across to the three year programme. It is possible to take a one year Interruption of Study if major professional or personal difficulties arise. This allows you to return to the programme exactly one year later. Up to two years of interruption may be requested. When on interruption you do not have access to College facilities.

metadata.title: Breaks in part-time study
key_points: Option to extend from two to three-year programme
Interruption of Study available for up to two years
No access to College facilities during interruption

content: Studying for a Master's degree is a step up from undergraduate work. At Master's level, your own learning and development is carried out in partnership with your lecturer. As your level of study increases, it is important to think more critically and reflectively about the information you encounter. Employers increasingly view inter-personal, team-working and communication skills as crucial when selecting new recruits. At the Master's level, you will be examined on a range of complex material that you will have learned from lecturers and your own independent study.

metadata.title: Study and research skills
key_points: Master's study is more advanced than undergraduate work
Critical thinking and reflection are crucial
Interpersonal and communication skills are highly valued

content: While each course is different, here are some general suggestions for pursuing your research: Take the initiative with your project, and think of your supervisor as an adviser, not a boss. Be ambitious. This is your chance to really hone and demonstrate your research skills. Prepare a timeline or timetable to help you plan your work and confirm that you can finish in time. Be orderly, precise and detailed, for example, in lab notebooks or when referencing. Look at examples of past projects, especially any that have been recommended to you. If you are collecting data, work out how you will analyse it before collecting it.

metadata.title: Choosing your project
key_points: Take initiative and be ambitious with your project
Plan your work with a timeline or timetable
Be organized and detailed in your research process

content: Critical thinking compels us to ask questions at several stages, such as: The formulation of the question - 'Am I asking the right questions?', Methods and evidence used - 'Is this a good way to investigate the question?', Any conclusions that are developed - 'Do these conclusions really reflect the evidence?' Critical thinking not only concerns evidence, but also challenges bias and ideology. Our own upbringing and environment can lead us to think in certain ways about things, but we can ask questions that tease these biases out.

metadata.title: Critical thinking and critical ability
key_points: Ask questions at various stages of research
Challenge bias and ideology in thinking
Evaluate methods, evidence, and conclusions critically

content: Reflect regularly on whether your study techniques are effective and be aware of the best times in the day for your study. It may be the case that you work better in the mornings but have planned lots of evening work therefore you will have to adjust your schedule. What is your overall goal? This can sometimes be a daunting question, especially when you are starting out in your degree, so it may help to divide your goals into manageable tasks. Establishing the difference between your short-term and long-term goals is a good start and can help you to visualise the steps to achieving them.

metadata.title: Time management
key_points: Regularly reflect on study techniques and timing
Divide overall goals into manageable tasks
Establish short-term and long-term goals

content: Lecturers may do a number of things, including: Organise and teach on the course, give you reading lists/recommendations and practice opportunities, provide support material, either on paper or online, set practical work for you, set formal and less formal assessments, suggest research projects or help you to identify projects that you can complete in your workplace based on your professional environment and circumstances, give you feedback through discussion or via comments written on your work. You will be expected to spend much of your time studying independently or with your peers, but your lecturers will be available if you need support.

metadata.title: What your teaching team expect from you
key_points: Lecturers provide various forms of support and guidance
Independent study is a significant part of the program
Seek support from lecturers when needed

content: Take advantage of learning and development opportunities beyond your programme. Keep in touch with what's going on. Being a member of Imperial gives you privileged access to the Imperial community â€“ use it.

metadata.title: 1. Soak up Imperial
key_points: Utilize learning opportunities beyond your program
Stay informed about Imperial activities
Take advantage of Imperial community access

content: Make lasting contact with students and staff across Imperial. Say yes to events and invitations â€“ you never know who you might meet and what you might learn. And look out for opportunities to make links with professionals and alumni beyond Imperial.

metadata.title: 2. Connect and network
key_points: Build connections with students and staff
Attend events and accept invitations
Seek opportunities to network with professionals and alumni

content: Question, critically analyse, think, build evidenceâ€“based arguments, create, be original, find your own voice and take ownership of your study and research.

metadata.title: 3. Think Master's level
key_points: Develop critical thinking and analysis skills
Build evidence-based arguments
Be original and find your own voice in research

content: A Master's is very intense, but plan your time so that you can live, think, have fun, be sociable and develop alongside your study and research.

metadata.title: 4. Balance your time
key_points: Recognize the intensity of Master's study
Plan time for personal life and socializing
Maintain balance between study and personal development

content: Did you know that many PhDs and UK employers start to recruit master's students as early as October (to start work a year later)? Visit the Careers Service early on in your time at Imperial for advice and support in developing your future plans.

metadata.title: 7. Consider what's next
key_points: Be aware of early recruitment timelines for PhDs and jobs
Visit the Careers Service early in your studies
Start planning your future career path early

content: Life has its ups and downs and if you're struggling on any level, Imperial has a range of support services and systems in place. Don't struggle on alone â€“ speak to someone, perhaps a friend, your personal tutor, someone from the programme team or any of the College's student support services.

metadata.title: 9. If you need help, ask
key_points: Recognize that challenges are normal
Utilize Imperial's support services when needed
Don't hesitate to ask for help from friends, tutors, or support staff

content: During your Master's degree, you will be expected to explore new perspectives, pursue your own research and add your own voice to the community in your field. Master a new skill, take up a new sport or embrace a new challenge â€“ never again are you likely to have such freedom to learn about yourself and what you enjoy. The benefits of studying and researching at Imperial go beyond the lecture theatre. When you are planning how to make the most of your Imperial experience, why not consider how to use the resources at the College to your advantage?

metadata.title: Beyond academic life
key_points: Explore new perspectives and pursue own research
Take advantage of opportunities for personal development
Utilize Imperial's resources beyond academics

content: During your Master's degree, you will be required to communicate in a variety of different ways. Strong communication and influencing skills are essential, not only as skills for education and studying, but also beyond into the workplace and the research environment. Learning how to communicate effectively with different audiences is hugely important in everything we do. This applies whether we are delivering a presentation, having a conversation, or writing something for a wider audience.

metadata.title: Communicating and influencing
key_points: Develop strong communication skills for various contexts
Learn to communicate effectively with different audiences
Essential for education, workplace, and research environment

content: There are certain things you can do before you arrive to help support your studies. We have collected some information to help you plan effectively before you join your course. A Master's degree is undoubtedly a big commitment. It is inevitable that you're going to feel pushed for time sometimes. This is totally normal, but there are ways to make it easier on yourself. Most programmes are designed to be studied full-time, but some can be completed part-time. Both have expectations of attendance and independent study.

metadata.title: Getting started
key_points: Prepare effectively before joining the course
Understand the commitment required for a Master's degree
Be aware of full-time and part-time study expectations

content: Part-time courses involve committing yourself to study for a period of two to three years. In this section, we explain the options open to you, and advise you on how to get the right support. Master's students are expected to take responsibility for their studies. However, we recognise that juggling a career and family with your academic life can be challenging. Here, we outline the support available to you.

metadata.title: Part-time study
key_points: Part-time courses typically last 2-3 years
Students must balance career, family, and academic life
Support available for part-time students

content: Studying for a Master's degree is a step up from undergraduate work. At Master's level, your own learning and development is carried out in partnership with your lecturer. As your level of study increases, it is important to think more critically and reflectively about the information you encounter. Employers increasingly view inter-personal, team-working and communication skills as crucial when selecting new recruits. At the Master's level, you will be examined on a range of complex material that you will have learned from lecturers and your own independent study.

metadata.title: Study and research skills
key_points: Master's study requires more critical thinking than undergraduate
Develop partnership with lecturers for learning
Focus on interpersonal and communication skills

content: Reflect regularly on whether your study techniques are effective and be aware of the best times in the day for your study. It may be the case that you work better in the mornings but have planned lots of evening work therefore you will have to adjust your schedule. What is your overall goal? This can sometimes be a daunting question, especially when you are starting out in your degree, so it may help to divide your goals into manageable tasks. Establishing the difference between your short-term and long-term goals is a good start and can help you to visualise the steps to achieving them.

metadata.title: Time management
key_points: Regularly assess and adjust study techniques
Identify optimal study times and adjust schedule accordingly
Break down overall goals into manageable tasks
